Title: RGB LED Control
LearningObjectives: Learn common cathode vs common anode
SafetyNotes: Use correct resistor values for each channel

Instructions.Title: Identify RGB LED Pins
Instructions.Description: Identify the four pins: Red, Common (longest), Green, and Blue.
Instructions.Tip: Common cathode means the longest pin goes to ground!

Instructions.Title: Connect Common Cathode
Instructions.Description: Connect the common cathode (longest pin) to ground.

Instructions.Title: Wire Red Channel
Instructions.Description: Connect Red pin through 220Ω resistor to first potentiometer.

Instructions.Title: Wire Green Channel
Instructions.Description: Connect Green pin through 220Ω resistor to second potentiometer.

Instructions.Title: Wire Blue Channel
Instructions.Description: Connect Blue pin through 220Ω resistor to third potentiometer.

Instructions.Title: Connect Power
Instructions.Description: Wire all potentiometers to positive power supply.

Instructions.Title: Mix Colors
Instructions.Description: Adjust each potentiometer to create different colors!
Instructions.Tip: Red + Green = Yellow, Red + Blue = Magenta, Green + Blue = Cyan!

FunFact: TV and computer screens use millions of tiny RGB LEDs or pixels to create every color you see!

Quiz.Question: What color do you get by mixing red and green light?
Quiz.Explanation: Red and green light combine to make yellow! This is additive color mixing, different from paint mixing.

Title: LED Matrix Basics
SafetyNotes: Use resistors on rows or columns
Don't short circuit rows and columns

Instructions.Title: Plan Matrix Layout
Instructions.Description: Draw a 4x4 grid and plan LED positions on breadboard.

Instructions.Title: Place LEDs
Instructions.Description: Insert 16 LEDs in 4 rows and 4 columns formation.
Instructions.Tip: Keep all anodes pointing same direction!

Instructions.Title: Connect Rows (Anodes)
Instructions.Description: Connect all anodes in each row together (4 row lines).

Instructions.Title: Connect Columns (Cathodes)
Instructions.Description: Connect all cathodes in each column together (4 column lines).

Instructions.Title: Add Row Resistors
Instructions.Description: Place 220Ω resistor on each of the 4 row lines.

Instructions.Title: Wire Row Switches
Instructions.Description: Connect 4 switches to control which row is powered.

Instructions.Title: Wire Column Switches
Instructions.Description: Connect 4 switches to control which columns go to ground.

Instructions.Title: Test Matrix
Instructions.Description: Turn on one row and one column switch to light one LED!
Instructions.Tip: Each LED is addressed by its row and column!

FunFact: LED scoreboards and electronic billboards use matrix displays with thousands of LEDs controlled by multiplexing!

Quiz.Question: In a 4x4 LED matrix, how many LEDs can you control with 8 wires (4 rows + 4 columns)?
Quiz.Explanation: A 4x4 matrix gives you 16 LEDs (4×4=16) controllable with just 8 wires! This is the power of matrix addressing.

Title: 7-Segment Display
AdditionalMaterials: Paper and pencil for segment mapping

Instructions.Title: Identify Segments
Instructions.Description: Learn the 7 segments labeled a, b, c, d, e, f, g plus decimal point.
Instructions.Tip: Top segment is 'a', going clockwise then middle is 'g'!

Instructions.Title: Insert Display
Instructions.Description: Place 7-segment display on breadboard, straddling center gap.

Instructions.Title: Connect Common Cathode
Instructions.Description: Identify and connect common cathode pins to ground.

Instructions.Title: Wire Segment A
Instructions.Description: Connect segment 'a' pin through resistor to DIP switch position 1.

Instructions.Title: Wire Remaining Segments
Instructions.Description: Connect segments b-g through resistors to DIP switches 2-7.

Instructions.Title: Connect Power
Instructions.Description: Wire all DIP switches to positive power rail.

Instructions.Title: Display Numbers
Instructions.Description: Flip switches to create numbers 0-9!
Instructions.Tip: For '0': turn on a,b,c,d,e,f. For '1': b,c only!

FunFact: 7-segment displays were invented in 1908 and are still used in digital clocks, meters, and calculators!

Quiz.Question: How many segments need to be lit to display the number '8'?
Quiz.Explanation: The number '8' requires all 7 segments to be lit! It uses the most segments of any digit.

Title: Multiplexing LEDs

Instructions.Title: Build Clock Circuit
Instructions.Description: Wire 555 timer in astable mode for ~100Hz clock signal.
Instructions.Tip: This creates the timing for multiplexing!

Instructions.Title: Setup 4017 Counter
Instructions.Description: Place 4017 decade counter IC on breadboard.

Instructions.Title: Connect Clock Input
Instructions.Description: Wire 555 output to 4017 clock input (pin 14).

Instructions.Title: Wire Output 0-3
Instructions.Description: Connect 4017 outputs 0-3 to first 4 LEDs through resistors.

Instructions.Title: Wire Output 4-7
Instructions.Description: Connect 4017 outputs 4-7 to remaining 4 LEDs through resistors.

Instructions.Title: Connect Reset
Instructions.Description: Wire 4017 output 8 back to reset pin to create 8-step sequence.

Instructions.Title: Test Sequence
Instructions.Description: Power on and watch LEDs light in sequence!
Instructions.Tip: LEDs light one at a time, sharing the counter IC!

FunFact: Multiplexing lets us control hundreds of LEDs with just a few wires - this is how LED matrices in signs and displays work!

Quiz.Question: What makes multiplexing work for human eyes?
Quiz.Explanation: Persistence of vision makes our eyes see rapidly flashing LEDs as continuously lit! This happens above ~50Hz.

Title: PWM Dimming

Instructions.Title: Setup 555 Timer
Instructions.Description: Wire 555 IC in astable mode on breadboard.

Instructions.Title: Add Diode Trick
Instructions.Description: Install diode across timing resistor for independent charge/discharge.
Instructions.Tip: This allows duty cycle from 0-100%!

Instructions.Title: Wire Potentiometer
Instructions.Description: Connect potentiometer to control timing and duty cycle.

Instructions.Title: Add Timing Components
Instructions.Description: Connect capacitor and resistors for ~1kHz PWM frequency.

Instructions.Title: Connect LEDs
Instructions.Description: Wire 3 LEDs in parallel from 555 output through resistors.

Instructions.Title: Test Dimming
Instructions.Description: Adjust potentiometer to dim LEDs from off to full brightness!
Instructions.Tip: LEDs change brightness smoothly without changing voltage!

FunFact: PWM dimming is more efficient than resistive dimming and is used in everything from phone screens to LED bulbs!

Quiz.Question: What is a 50% duty cycle?
Options: On half the time, off half the time
Quiz.Explanation: A 50% duty cycle means the signal is on for half the time and off for half the time in each cycle!

Title: Color Mixing

Instructions.Title: Build Red PWM
Instructions.Description: Create 555 PWM circuit with potentiometer for red channel.

Instructions.Title: Build Green PWM
Instructions.Description: Create second 555 PWM circuit for green channel.

Instructions.Title: Build Blue PWM
Instructions.Description: Create third 555 PWM circuit for blue channel.

Instructions.Title: Wire RGB LEDs
Instructions.Description: Connect 3 RGB LEDs with common cathodes to ground.
Instructions.Tip: Place LEDs close together for better color mixing!

Instructions.Title: Connect Red Outputs
Instructions.Description: Wire red PWM output to all red channels through resistors.

Instructions.Title: Connect Green & Blue
Instructions.Description: Wire green and blue PWM outputs to respective channels.

Instructions.Title: Add Diffuser
Instructions.Description: Place white diffuser over LEDs to blend colors smoothly.

Instructions.Title: Mix Colors
Instructions.Description: Adjust three pots to create any color of the rainbow!
Instructions.Tip: Try creating orange, pink, purple, and white!

FunFact: The human eye has three types of color receptors (red, green, blue), which is why RGB mixing can create all visible colors!

Quiz.Question: What color do you get with all three RGB channels at full brightness?
Quiz.Explanation: Red + Green + Blue at full brightness creates white light! This is how white LEDs in screens are made.

Title: LED Chaser Circuit
AdditionalMaterials: Strip of cardboard for LED mounting

Instructions.Title: Build 555 Oscillator
Instructions.Description: Create variable frequency oscillator with potentiometer control.

Instructions.Title: Setup 4017 Counter
Instructions.Description: Place 4017 decade counter IC on breadboard.

Instructions.Title: Connect Clock
Instructions.Description: Wire 555 output to 4017 clock input (pin 14).

Instructions.Title: Mount LEDs in Line
Instructions.Description: Place 10 LEDs in a straight line on breadboard.
Instructions.Tip: Space them evenly for best visual effect!

Instructions.Title: Wire Output 0-4
Instructions.Description: Connect 4017 outputs 0-4 to first 5 LEDs through resistors.

Instructions.Title: Wire Output 5-9
Instructions.Description: Connect 4017 outputs 5-9 to remaining LEDs through resistors.

Instructions.Title: Connect LED Cathodes
Instructions.Description: Wire all LED cathodes to common ground.

Instructions.Title: Test Chase Pattern
Instructions.Description: Power on and adjust speed pot to control chase rate!
Instructions.Tip: Try fast and slow speeds for different effects!

FunFact: Knight Rider's KITT car used a similar LED chaser effect that became iconic in the 1980s!

Quiz.Question: What does a decade counter do?
Quiz.Explanation: A decade counter counts from 0 to 9 (10 states total), then resets back to 0!

Title: Ambient Light Sensor

Instructions.Title: Build Sensor Circuit
Instructions.Description: Create voltage divider with LDR and 10kΩ resistor.
Instructions.Tip: LDR resistance changes with light level!

Instructions.Title: Add Sensitivity Control
Instructions.Description: Wire potentiometer to adjust sensitivity range.

Instructions.Title: Setup LM3914
Instructions.Description: Place LM3914 LED bar graph driver on breadboard.

Instructions.Title: Connect Signal Input
Instructions.Description: Wire LDR voltage divider output to LM3914 signal input (pin 5).

Instructions.Title: Wire LEDs
Instructions.Description: Connect 5 LEDs to LM3914 outputs 1-5 through resistors.

Instructions.Title: Set Bar Mode
Instructions.Description: Configure LM3914 for bar graph mode (pin 9 to positive).

Instructions.Title: Test Light Levels
Instructions.Description: Cover and uncover LDR to see LED bar graph respond!
Instructions.Tip: More light = more LEDs lit!

FunFact: Your smartphone automatically adjusts screen brightness using a similar ambient light sensor!

Quiz.Question: What happens to an LDR's resistance in bright light?
Quiz.Explanation: LDR resistance decreases dramatically in bright light, allowing more current to flow!

Title: Light-Activated Switch
SafetyNotes: Test with low voltage loads first

Instructions.Title: Build Sensor Divider
Instructions.Description: Create voltage divider with LDR and 10kΩ resistor.

Instructions.Title: Build Reference
Instructions.Description: Create adjustable reference voltage with potentiometer.

Instructions.Title: Wire Op-Amp Comparator
Instructions.Description: Connect LM358 as comparator with LDR on + input, reference on - input.
Instructions.Tip: Output goes high when light level exceeds threshold!

Instructions.Title: Add Transistor Switch
Instructions.Description: Wire 2N2222 transistor with base from op-amp output.

Instructions.Title: Connect Relay
Instructions.Description: Wire relay coil to transistor collector.

Instructions.Title: Add Protection Diode
Instructions.Description: Install diode across relay coil (cathode to positive).

Instructions.Title: Wire Indicator LEDs
Instructions.Description: Connect LEDs to show sensor state and relay state.

Instructions.Title: Calibrate Threshold
Instructions.Description: Adjust potentiometer to set light level trigger point!
Instructions.Tip: Relay clicks when light crosses threshold!

FunFact: Automatic street lights use this exact principle to turn on at dusk and off at dawn!

Quiz.Question: What does a comparator do?
Quiz.Explanation: A comparator compares two input voltages and outputs high or low based on which is larger!

Title: Build a Mood Lamp

Instructions.Title: Build Slow Oscillator
Instructions.Description: Create 555 timer circuit with ~10 second period using large capacitor.

Instructions.Title: Setup Color Sequencer
Instructions.Description: Wire 4017 counter to create 10-step color sequence.

Instructions.Title: Program Color Steps
Instructions.Description: Wire outputs to RGB channels to create color sequence: Red→Orange→Yellow→Green→Cyan→Blue→Purple→Pink→White→Off.
Instructions.Tip: Use combinations of R/G/B to create each color!

Instructions.Title: Connect RGB LEDs
Instructions.Description: Wire 6 RGB LEDs in parallel with common cathodes to ground.

Instructions.Title: Wire Color Channels
Instructions.Description: Connect all red, green, and blue channels to sequencer outputs.

Instructions.Title: Test Color Sequence
Instructions.Description: Power on and verify smooth color transitions.

Instructions.Title: Prepare Housing
Instructions.Description: Prepare jar or container with diffuser material inside.

Instructions.Title: Mount LEDs
Instructions.Description: Secure LEDs inside housing pointing toward diffuser.
Instructions.Tip: Space LEDs evenly for uniform illumination!

Instructions.Title: Install Circuit
Instructions.Description: Mount breadboard in base with access to speed control pot.

Instructions.Title: Final Assembly
Instructions.Description: Assemble housing, secure all parts, and test final lamp!
Instructions.Tip: Make sure pot is accessible for speed adjustment!

FunFact: Philips Hue smart bulbs use similar RGB LED technology with millions of color combinations!

Quiz.Question: Why use a diffuser in a mood lamp?
Quiz.Explanation: A diffuser scatters and blends the light from individual LEDs, creating smooth uniform colors without visible spots!
